de.esoco.lib.text

Class TextConvert

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.text.TextConvert

  • public class TextConvert
extends java.lang.Object
    A utility class that contains static methods for text conversions.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  TextConvert.IdentifierStyle
      Enumeration of the styles for the conversion of identifiers.

    • Method Detail

      • capitalize

        public static java.lang.String capitalize(java.lang.String sText,
                                          java.lang.String sSeparator)
        Creates a capitalized string. This is done by splitting the input string at whitespace (regular expression '\s'), underscores ('_'), or dots and concatenating the resulting words capitalized and separated by the given separator string.
        Parameters:
        sText - The input string
        sSeparator - The separator string or NULL for none
        Returns:
        The capitalized identifier string

      • capitalize

        public static java.lang.String capitalize(java.lang.String sText,
                                          java.lang.String sSeparator,
                                          boolean bFirstWordLowerCase)
        Creates a capitalized string. This is done by splitting the input string at whitespace (regular expression '\s'), underscores ('_'), or dots and concatenating the resulting words capitalized and separated by the given separator string.
        Parameters:
        sText - The input string
        sSeparator - The separator string or NULL for none
        bFirstWordLowerCase - TRUE to keep the first word in lower case
        Returns:
        The capitalized identifier string

      • capitalizedIdentifier

        public static java.lang.String capitalizedIdentifier(java.lang.String sIdentifier)
        Creates a capitalized identifier from a string. This method invokes capitalize(String, String) without a separator string. If the input string has the correct format already it will be returned unchanged. The counterpart is uppercaseIdentifier(String).

        Examples:

        • 'foo bar' becomes FooBar
        • FOO_BAZ_BAR becomes FooBazBar
        Parameters:
        sIdentifier - The string to create the identifier from
        Returns:
        The capitalized identifier string

      • capitalizedLastElementOf

        public static java.lang.String capitalizedLastElementOf(java.lang.String sInput)
        Shortcut method that returns the capitalizedIdentifier(String) after applying lastElementOf(String) to an input string.
        Parameters:
        sInput - The input string
        Returns:
        The resulting identifier

      • capitalizedWord

        public static java.lang.String capitalizedWord(java.lang.String sWord)
        Capitalizes a word.
        Parameters:
        sWord - The word to capitalize
        Returns:
        sWord[0].toUpperCase + sWord[1..length-1].toLowerCase

        Parameters:
        eStyle - The style to convert to
        sIdentifier - The identifier to convert
        Returns:

      • format

        public static java.lang.String format(java.lang.String sFormat,
                                      java.lang.Object... rArgs)
        A varargs variant of format(String, Collection).
        See Also:
        format(String, Collection)

      • format

        public static java.lang.String format(java.lang.String sFormat,
                                      java.util.Collection<java.lang.Object> rArgs)
        A simplified version of String.format(String, Object...) that is also available in constrained environments like GWT but only supports string values. It replaces all occurrences of placeholders (%s) with the toString() representations of the argument objects. Placeholders may be indexed (e.g. %1$s) in which case they can also occur multiple times. If not enough placeholders occur in the text string any surplus values will be ignored.
        Parameters:
        sFormat - The format string
        rArgs - The values to place in the format string
        Returns:
        The formatted result string

      • hexChar

        public static char hexChar(int nValue)
        To convert a integer value between 0 and 15 into the corresponding character of the hexadecimal representation (0-9,A-F). This method is very simple and does no validation so that using values outside the allowed range will yield no reasonable result.
        Parameters:
        nValue - The value to convert, in the range 0 to 15
        Returns:
        The corresponding hex character (letters are upper case)

      • hexString

        public static java.lang.String hexString(byte[] rBytes,
                                         java.lang.String sFill)
        To create a hexadecimal string representation of a byte array. Each byte will be displayed as a two-character upper case hexadecimal value. The two-char values will be separated by the given fill string. The size of the resulting string will be (rBytes.length x (2 + sFill.length()) - sFill.length() .
        Parameters:
        rBytes - The byte array to display (the values will not be changed)
        sFill - A String to be inserted between the two-char hex values
        Returns:
        The resulting hexadecimal string

      • hexString

        public static java.lang.String hexString(byte[] rBytes,
                                         int nOffset,
                                         int nCount,
                                         java.lang.String sFill)
        To create a hexadecimal string representation of a byte array. Each byte will be displayed as a two-character upper case hexadecimal value. The two-char values will be separated by the given fill string. The size of the resulting string will be (rBytes.length x (2 + sFill.length()) - sFill.length() .

        The method will always read a maximum of (rBytes.length - nOffset) bytes from the array even if the value of nOffset + nCount is larger.

        Parameters:
        rBytes - The byte array to display (the values will not be changed)
        nOffset - The position to start reading bytes from
        nCount - The number of bytes to display
        sFill - A String to be inserted between the two-char hex values
        Returns:
        The resulting hexadecimal string

      • interleave

        public static java.lang.String interleave(java.lang.String sValue,
                                          java.lang.String sFill,
                                          int nChunkSize)
        Interleaves a string with a fill string in certain intervals.
        Parameters:
        sValue - The value to interleave with the fill string
        sFill - The string to insert between the value chunks
        nChunkSize - The size of the chunks between the fill string shall be inserted (negative to start from the string end)
        Returns:
        The resulting string

      • lastElementOf

        public static java.lang.String lastElementOf(java.lang.String sInput)
        Extracts the last element of a string that is separated by dots ('.'). If the input string does not contain dots it is returned unchanged.
        Parameters:
        sInput - The input string
        Returns:
        The resulting string

      • numberString

        public static java.lang.String numberString(int nNumber)
        Converts an integer value into a descriptive English string in lower case (e.g. 1 = "one"). If a number cannot be mapped NULL will be returned. The current implementation only supports the numbers from 0 (zero) to 20 (twenty).
        Parameters:
        nNumber - The number to convert
        Returns:
        The resulting string or NULL if no conversion was possible

      • padCenter

        public static java.lang.String padCenter(java.lang.String sString,
                                         int nWidth,
                                         char cFill)
        Returns a string that is centered within a certain maximum length. If the input string's length is less than the target length it will be aligned at the center of the resulting string and the left and right will be padded with the given fill character. If the length of the string to pad is uneven padding on the right side takes precedence so that the string will be aligned one character farther to the left.
        Parameters:
        sString - The string to be padded
        nWidth - The length of the result string
        cFill - The fill character
        Returns:
        The resulting string

      • padLeft

        public static java.lang.String padLeft(java.lang.String sString,
                                       int nWidth,
                                       char cFill)
        Returns a right-aligned string with a certain maximum length. If the input string's length is less than the target length it will be aligned to the right of the resulting string and the left will be filled with the given fill character.
        Parameters:
        sString - The string to be padded
        nWidth - The length of the result string
        cFill - The fill character
        Returns:
        The resulting string

      • padRight

        public static java.lang.String padRight(java.lang.String sString,
                                        int nWidth,
                                        char cFill)
        Returns a left-aligned string with a certain maximum length. If the input string's length is less than the target length it will be aligned to the left of the resulting string and the right will be filled with the given fill character.
        Parameters:
        sString - The string to be padded
        nWidth - The length of the result string
        cFill - The fill character
        Returns:
        The resulting string

        public static java.lang.String toPlural(java.lang.String sName)
        Returns the English plural of a certain name.
        Parameters:
        sName - The name to convert
        Returns:
        The resulting plural name

      • unicodeDecode

        public static java.lang.String unicodeDecode(java.lang.String sValue,
                                             java.lang.String sToken)
        Decodes all occurrences of the Java and JavaScript unicode escape representation with the un-escaped token.
        Parameters:
        sValue - The value string to escape the occurrences of
        sToken - The separator string to escape
        Returns:
        The escaped string

      • unicodeEncode

        public static java.lang.String unicodeEncode(java.lang.String sValue)
        Encodes each character of a string with it's unicode escape sequence.
        Parameters:
        sValue - The value to encode
        Returns:
        The encoded value

      • unicodeEncode

        public static java.lang.Object unicodeEncode(java.lang.String sValue,
                                             java.lang.String sToken)
        Encodes all occurrences of a token string in a value string with their Java and JavaScript unicode escape representation.
        Parameters:
        sValue - The value string to escape the occurrences of
        sToken - The separator string to escape
        Returns:
        The escaped string

      • uppercaseIdentifier

        public static java.lang.String uppercaseIdentifier(java.lang.String sIdentifier)
        Creates an upper case identifier from a string. This is done by inserting underscores ('_') at single upper case letters or after sequences of such and by converting the resulting string to upper case. Whitespace characters will also be replaced with underscores. This method is the counterpart to capitalizedIdentifier(String).

        Examples:

        • Foobar, foobar, and FOOBAR become FOOBAR
        • FooBar becomes FOO_BAR
        • aFooBar becomes A_FOO_BAR
        • FooBAZBar becomes FOO_BAZ_BAR
        • Foo_Bar becomes FOO_BAR
        • Foo Bar becomes FOO_BAR
        Parameters:
        sIdentifier - The string to create the upper case identifier from
        Returns:
        The upper case identifier string
